title: Modern Physics - Wiens law photoelectric effect

content.question:
Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

In Experiment <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, students are asked to determine an experimental value for Wien’s constant, <math alttext="b" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>b</mi></math>, which appears in the equation for Wien’s law: <math alttext="lambda sub max equals, the fraction b over T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>λ</mi><mi>max</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mi>b</mi><mi>T</mi></mfrac></math>. The students have access to a bulb that approximates the spectral output of a blackbody and a sensor that can record the intensity of the light emitted by the bulb as a function of wavelength. The temperature of the bulb can be varied, and the students have access to a sensor that can measure the temperature of the bulb.

(a) Describe a procedure for collecting data that would allow the students to use a graph to determine Wien’s constant, <math alttext="b" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>b</mi></math>. Provide enough detail so that the students could replicate the experiment, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

In Experiment <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, the students have a glass vacuum chamber with two parallel metal plates inside, as shown. The students are asked to use the setup to determine the work function of the metal plates. In each trial, the students use a monochromatic light source with wavelength <math alttext="lambda" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>λ</mi></math> to shine light on one of the plates. Once current is detected, the students increase the potential difference <math alttext="delta V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Δ</mtext><mi>V</mi></math> of the power supply until the ammeter reads zero. In each trial, the students adjust the light source to a different wavelength <math alttext="lambda" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>λ</mi></math>. They collect the following data on the wavelengths of the incident light and the potential difference from the power supply when the current stops.

i. Indicate what measured and/or calculated quantities could be graphed to yield a straight line that could be used to determine the work function of the metal. Use the blank columns in the table to list any calculated quantities you will graph other than the data provided.
